hints.content:
We can use the related multiplication equation to help us.

$\goldE{38} \div \blueE{4} = \maroonE{{?}}$

So, $\blueE{4} \times \maroonE{{?}}= \goldE{38}$.

No whole number value of $\maroonE{{?}}$ makes the equation exactly true. 

Let's try different values of $\maroonE{?}$ to get close to a product of $\goldE{38}$.

$\begin{align}
\blueE{4} \times \maroonE{8} &= 32 \\\\
\blueE{4} \times \maroonE{9} &= 36 \\\\
\blueE{4} \times \maroonE{10} &= 40
\end{align}$

Which two values of $\maroonE{?}$ get us the closest to $\goldE{38}$?
The total $\goldE{38}$ is between $36$ and $40$, so $\maroonE{?}$ is between $\maroonE{9}$ and $\maroonE{10}$.

The point that represents $\goldE{38} \div \blueE{4}$ is between $\maroonE{9}$ and $\maroonE{10}$.

[[☃ image 1]]

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
[[☃ image 1]]

It takes more than $\maroonE{9}$ rows of $\blueE{4}$, but less than $\maroonE{10}$ full rows of $\blueE{4}$ to equal $\goldE{38}$.
options.showPrompt: Please show me a picture of what this means.

options.alt: An array of 38 circles arranged in 9 rows of 4 circles each and 1 row with 2 circles.
A number line from 5 to 10, with a tick every 1 unit. A point is labeled between the tick mark labeled 9 and the tick mark labeled 10. !

question.content:
The following quotient is between two whole numbers.

$38 \div 4$

**Which point on the number line could represent the quotient?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
